title: Social Awareness and Community Development - Comprehensive Test
description: Comprehensive test covering social service basics, rural development programs, NGOs, youth contribution, social evils, civic responsibilities, and relevant legislation

questions.text: When was the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (NREGA) launched, which was later renamed MGNREGA?
questions.explanation: NREGA was launched on 2nd February 2006 and was later renamed as Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) in 2010.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the Swarnajayanti Gram Swarojgar Yojna (SGSY)?

options.b: To provide sustainable income to rural poor

questions.explanation: SGSY aims to provide sustainable income to the rural poor by establishing micro-enterprises based on the potential of rural poor.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT one of the three accepted methods of social service?
questions.explanation: The three accepted methods are Social Case Work, Social Group Work, and Community Organization. Political Mobilization is not considered a core method of social service.

questions.text: What percentage of benefits under SGSY are reserved for women?
questions.explanation: Under SGSY, special safeguards include reserving 50% of benefits for SCs/STs, 40% for women, and 3% for physically handicapped persons.

questions.text: Which government ministry is responsible for administering rural development programs in India?
questions.explanation: The Ministry of Rural Development is responsible for rural development programs and includes two departments: Department of Rural Development and Department of Land Resources.

questions.text: What is the guaranteed number of days of wage employment provided under MGNREGA?
questions.explanation: MGNREGA provides at least 100 days of guaranteed wage employment in a financial year to every household whose adult members volunteer to do unskilled manual work.

questions.text: Which of these programs is specifically aimed at providing rural housing?
questions.explanation: Indira Aawas Yojna (IAY) is the flagship rural housing scheme aimed at providing shelter to the poor below poverty line.

questions.text: What is the main objective of National Social Assistance Programme (NSAP)?

options.b: To provide social security to elderly, widows and disabled

questions.explanation: NSAP provides social assistance to the elderly, widow and disabled persons through various pension schemes and assistance programs.

questions.text: Which rural development program focuses on providing all-weather road connectivity?
questions.explanation: Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) was launched to provide connectivity by all weather roads to unconnected habitations.

questions.text: What does the term 'INGO' stand for in the context of NGOs?
questions.explanation: INGO stands for International NGOs, which operate across international boundaries.

questions.text: Which of these is an example of an International NGO mentioned in the lesson?
questions.explanation: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is mentioned as the world's largest group of humanitarian NGOs.

questions.text: What percentage of India's population is below 18 years according to the lesson?
questions.explanation: According to the lesson, almost 42% of India's total population is under eighteen years of age.

questions.text: Which act provides protection to children from sexual offences?

options.a: Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act 2012

questions.explanation: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act was passed in 2012 and received President's assent on 19th June 2012.

questions.text: What is the punishment for penetrative sexual assault under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act?
questions.explanation: Penetrative Sexual Assault carries punishment of not less than seven years imprisonment, which may extend to imprisonment for life and fine.

questions.text: Which commission is designated to monitor the implementation of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act?

options.c: National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

questions.explanation: The National Commission for the Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR) and State Commissions are designated to monitor implementation of the Act.

questions.text: What is the legal Blood Alcohol Level (BAC) limit for driving in India?
questions.explanation: In India, if a person has Blood Alcohol Level exceeding 30 mg per 100 ml of blood detected by Breathalyzer, it is considered drunk driving.

questions.text: Which of these is identified as the most common violator of drunk driving laws?
questions.explanation: The most common violators are identified as children between 16-25 years, truck drivers, people returning from pubs/parties, and after New Year or Holi celebrations.

questions.text: What percentage of road accidents in India are caused due to driver's fault according to the lesson?
questions.explanation: According to the lesson, almost 78% of all road accidents in India are caused due to driver's fault.

questions.text: When was the Right to Information Act passed by the Indian Parliament?
questions.explanation: The Right to Information Bill was passed by both Houses of Parliament in May 2005 and received President's assent on 15th June 2005.

questions.text: Which of these states is exempted from the Right to Information Act?
questions.explanation: The RTI Act covers the whole of India except Jammu and Kashmir, where J&K Right to Information Act is in force.

questions.text: What percentage of seats in private schools are reserved for poor families under RTE Act?
questions.explanation: The RTE Act requires all private schools to reserve 25% of seats to children from poor families, to be reimbursed by the state.

questions.text: When was the Right to Education Act enforced in India?
questions.explanation: The RTE Act was enforced on 1st April 2010, making India one of 135 countries to make education a fundamental right.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT a form of child abuse as defined in the lesson?
questions.explanation: The forms of child abuse defined include Physical Abuse, Emotional Abuse, Sexual Abuse, Child Neglect, and Unreasonable Deprivation.

questions.text: According to the National Study on Child Abuse, what percentage of children reported facing physical abuse?
questions.explanation: The National Study on Child Abuse found that two out of every three children (69%) were physically abused.

questions.text: What is the definition of female foeticide?
questions.explanation: Female foeticide is defined as the selective abortion/elimination of the girl child in the womb itself after detection of gender through medical means.

questions.text: What was the sex ratio in India according to 2011 census?
questions.explanation: The sex ratio had plummeted to an all-time low of only 914 girls for 1000 boys in 2011 census.

questions.text: Which of these is a major cause of female foeticide?
questions.explanation: The dowry system is cited as a major cause of female foeticide as girls are seen as a burden due to marriage expenses.

questions.text: What is the punishment for giving or taking dowry under Dowry Prohibition Act?
questions.explanation: The Dowry Prohibition Act states imprisonment for not less than five years and fine not less than fifteen thousand rupees.

questions.text: Which organization monitors the implementation of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act at state level?

options.b: State Commission for Protection of Child Rights

questions.explanation: State Commissions for Protection of Child Rights (SCPCRs) are designated to monitor implementation at state level.

questions.text: What is the time limit for recording evidence of a child under Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act?
questions.explanation: For speedy trial, the Act provides that evidence of the child should be recorded within 30 days.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT a method of family planning mentioned in the lesson?
questions.explanation: The methods mentioned are Vasectomy, Tubectomy, Conventional contraceptives like condoms, and Oral pills.

questions.text: What is the most common route of HIV transmission according to the lesson?
questions.explanation: Sexual transmission is identified as the most common route of HIV spread through unprotected sex.

questions.text: Which group is at greater risk of HIV transmission through unprotected sex?
questions.explanation: Women are at greater risk of developing HIV infection through unprotected sex due to biological and social factors.

questions.text: What does NACO stand for?
questions.explanation: NACO stands for National AIDS Control Organisation, which is responsible for HIV/AIDS policy and program implementation in India.

questions.text: Which of these is a type of terrorist incident mentioned in the lesson?
questions.explanation: Cyber Terrorism is mentioned as a new form of terrorism that allows terrorists to operate with little risk.

questions.text: What is the full form of NCTC in counter-terrorism context?
questions.explanation: NCTC stands for National Counter Terrorism Center, established to deal with terrorist threats.

questions.text: Which of these is considered 'Petty Corruption'?
questions.explanation: Petty corruption occurs at smaller scale and includes exchange of small improper gifts or use of personal connections.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of Jawahar Gram Samriddhi Yojna (JGSY)?
questions.explanation: JGSY's primary objective is creation of demand-driven community village infrastructure including durable assets.

questions.text: Which program was restructured as National Rural Livelihoods Mission (NRLM)?
questions.explanation: SGSY has been restructured as National Rural Livelihoods Mission (NRLM) and renamed as 'Aajeevika'.

questions.text: What is the duration of Annual Training Camps for senior division NCC cadets?
questions.explanation: Annual Training Camps are of 12 days duration for senior boys/girls and 10 days for junior boys/girls.

questions.text: Which organization provides financial assistance to cadets for injuries during NCC activities?
questions.explanation: Cadet Welfare Society (CWS) provides financial assistance and relief to cadets for injuries during NCC activities.

questions.text: What percentage of vacancies in Air Force courses are reserved for NCC 'C' certificate holders?
questions.explanation: 10% vacancies in all Air Force courses are reserved for NCC 'C' certificate holders through Air Force SSB.

questions.text: Which training involves attachment with army/naval/air force units in NCC?
questions.explanation: Attachment Training is formal training organized by attachment with armed forces units or officer training academies.

questions.text: What is the main objective of Youth Exchange Programme (YEP) in NCC?

options.b: To interact with youths of friendly foreign countries

questions.explanation: YEP sends selected cadets to friendly foreign countries for 10-day visits to promote international understanding.

questions.text: How many Directorates does NCC have across India?
questions.explanation: There are 17 Directorates located in state capitals, headed by officers of Major General/Brigadier rank or equivalent.

questions.text: What is the current approximate enrolled strength of NCC cadets?
questions.explanation: NCC has an enrolled strength of more than 13 Lakh cadets comprising Senior and Junior divisions.

questions.text: Which of these is a Centrally Organised Camp (COC) in NCC?
questions.explanation: Leadership Camps (Basic and Advance) are Centrally Organised Camps planned by HQ DG NCC for all-India participation.

questions.text: How many seats are reserved for NCC 'C' certificate holders at IMA per year?
questions.explanation: 64 seats per year are reserved at Indian Military Academy (IMA) for NCC 'C' certificate holders as officers.

questions.text: Which of these states provides reservation in police department for NCC certificate holders?
questions.explanation: Jammu & Kashmir reserves 10% or one post in non-gazetted police services for NCC 'C' certificate holders.

questions.text: What benefit do NCC cadets get for recruitment in ranks of armed forces?
questions.explanation: NCC cadets get 5-10% bonus marks for recruitment in ranks in Army, Navy and Air Force.
